candidates.title: chore: move to `async-graphql-parser`

labels.name: fuel-explorer
labels.description: This PR is directly related to the block explorer

candidates.body:
## Changelog
- Move packages from use of `graphql-parser`/`fuel-indexer-graphql-parser` to `async-graphql-parser`
- Remove `fuel-indexer-graphql-parser` package
- Adjust tests

## Testing Plan
CI should pass.

### Manual Testing
Feel free to run the block explorer example with the simple and complex example queries from the documentation.

## Notes
This is the first step in integrating `async-graphql` into the indexer.

candidates.title: fix: update docs/examples
candidates.body:
### Description
- PR does a few things
  - Updates docs for the examples
  - Removes `api-server` and `fuel-core-lib` feature flagging from native execution
  - Fixes a bug in `forc index deploy` where the `--path` isn't respected relative to the `--target-dir`

### Testing steps 
- [ ] Build plugin locally `cargo build -p forc-index --release --locked`
- [ ] Start fuel node `cargo run -p fuel-node --bin fuel-node`
- [ ] Start the service `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations`
- [ ] `cd examples/block-explorer && forc-index deploy --path explorer-indexer --target-dir /path/to/fuel-indexer` 
  - This ☝🏽 would fail on master


### Changelog 
- docs: update docs for examples 
- fix: ensure that `forc index deploy` respects `--path` relative to `--target-dir`

candidates.title: chore: bump to rustc 1.69
candidates.body:
### Description
- PR updates everything to use rust 1.69
- Also fixes a flaky test related to prometheus metrics

### Testing steps
- [ ] Docker build should pass `docker build -t fuel-indexer/local:latest -f deployment/Dockerfile .`

### Changelog 
- chore: bump to rustc 1.69

candidates.title: chore: move common crates to workspace
candidates.body:
clap, fuel-tx, fuels, serde, thiserror, tokio, tracing

generated with

```
cargo dependency-inheritor -w Cargo.toml -n 8
```

candidates.title: enhancement: convert Scalar types into `Json` and `Blob`

labels.name: breaking
labels.description: This is a change that will break some component of the project once merged to origin/develop

candidates.body:
Closes #843

## Changelog
• Adds the macros`json_impl` and `blob_impl` macros for custom Scalar types. 
• Adds unit tests testing the underlying types of our scalar types.
• Changes the type of Blob from an alias to a custom type (see note below about this)
• Updates code elsewhere to integrate the Blob type. 

## NB
I had to make Blob a custom type as apposed to just an alias as it was before. This is because I could not implement a custom `From` trait on an alias of underlying type`Vec<u8>`. But when `Blob is :
```rust
pub struct Blob(pub Vec<u8>);
```
I can implement the From trait. This is because of the orphan rule.

##Testing
This unit test wont run in CI. I don't think we need it to necessarily, but to run the tests cd into 
`packages/fuel-indexer-types/src/` and run `cargo test` this will run the newly created unit tests in the `lib.rs` file

You want to see: 
```
running 8 tests
test tests::test_into_json_blob_int16 ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_id ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_int4 ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_int8 ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_timestamp ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_uint16 ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_uint4 ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_uint8 ... ok
```

candidates.title: chore: use `[default-members]` section in `Cargo.toml`
candidates.body:
Closes #842.

## Changelog
- Introduce `[default-members]` section
- Change member inclusion to be more idiomatic

## Testing Plan
CI should pass.

## Notes
This change was done to prevent the issue of failed builds when running `cargo build` in the repository root. This structure comes from the [`axum` project](https://github.com/tokio-rs/axum/blob/main/Cargo.toml).

This change also reduces the overall build time of a bare `cargo build`, but makes changes to using the internal testing components. To use internal testing components, a dev should use `cargo run -p [package] --bin [package]`. So in this case of `fuel-node`, one would start it by using `cargo run -p fuel-node --bin fuel-node`.

candidates.title: enhancement: add histogram reporting to postgres
candidates.body:
### Description
- PR integrates our database backend with Prometheus
  - We already _sort've_ had an integration but it was more of a placeholder
  - Now that I've been able to play with our Grafana I can see that we'll want to record these histogram stats for queries, and we will also want to make it pretty generic 
- Adds a new crate `fuel-indexer-macro-utils`
  - Can't use `fuel-indexer-macros` because that's a cyclic dependency 
  - `fuel-indexer-macro-utils` is for macros used for internal devs (`fuel-indexer-macros` is more so for external users)
  - Crate reservation is here https://github.com/FuelLabs/crate-reservations/pull/26
- Also adds `--locked --no-default-features` arg to `cargo-verifications`

### Testing steps
- [ ] CI should pass, as it was updated
- [ ] Start the service connected to beta-3 `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80`
- [ ] Make a request to the metrics endpoint, you should see the new metrics

```
curl http://localhost:29987/api/metrics
# HELP web_request_duration .
# TYPE web_request_duration histogram
# EOF
# HELP postgres_operation_duration .
# TYPE postgres_operation_duration histogram
postgres_operation_duration_sum{path="put_object"} 8.0
postgres_operation_duration_count{path="put_object"} 300
postgres_operation_duration_bucket{le="0.0",path="put_object"} 292
postgres_operation_duration_bucket{le="10.0",path="put_object"} 300
postgres_operation_duration_bucket{le="100.0",path="put_object"} 300

postgres_operation_duration_bucket{le="100000.0",path="put_object"} 300
postgres_operation_duration_bucket{le="500000.0",path="put_object"} 300
postgres_operation_duration_bucket{le="1000000.0",path="put_object"} 300
postgres_operation_duration_bucket{le="+Inf",path="put_object"} 300
```

- enhancement: add histogram reporting to postgres

candidates.title: fix: add postgres package features
candidates.body:
### Description
- Noticed while playing around in Grafana that none of the `postgres_*` database Prometheus metrics were working
- Saw that we're not including the `metrics` feature in `fuel-indexer-database/postgres`

### Testing steps
- [ ] Build docker image locally `docker build -t fuel-indexer/local:latest -f deployment/Dockerfile .`
- [ ] Update the block-explorer docker-compose with the local image `image: fuel-indexer/local:latest`
- [ ] Compose up `docker-compose up`
- [ ] Make a few requests to some endpoints a few times:
  - `curl http://0.0.0.0:29987/api/health`
  - `curl http://0.0.0.0:29987/api/graph/fuel_examples/explorer_indexer`
- [ ] Make a request to metrics `curl http://0.0.0.0:29987/api/metrics`
- [ ] Grep for `postgres_execute_query_calls` in the response and it should have multiple `calls`
  - Currently `curl https://beta-3-indexer.fuel.network/api/metrics` has a `calls` value of `0`

### Changelog
- fix: add postgres package features

candidates.title: bug: fix feature flag on `fuel-indexer-schema` for `fuel-indexer-graphql`
candidates.body:
This is blocking the full publishing of the `fuel-indexer-*` crates.

## Changelog
- Add `db-models` feature to `fuel-indexer-schema` dependency in `fuel-indexer-graphql`
- Remove unnecessary `default-features = false` on dependencies to get rid of warnings

## Testing Plan
CI should pass.

candidates.title: enhancement: add prometheus metrics middleware
candidates.body:
### Description
- This is a carry-over of https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/pull/777
- Inspired by fuel-core's version of this https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-core/commit/141669577c73bd0a6a67a6e6ab6796385b7f5b4a
- This PR adds middleware to our Axum server that integrates with Prometheus metrics

### Testing steps
- [ ] Build `fuel-indexer-api-server` without default features 
  - `cargo build -p fuel-indexer-api-server --no-default-features`
- [ ] Tests were updated so CI should pass
- [ ] Spin up the service and test out the metrics endpoint
  - `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations`
  - Hit a web endpoint a few times `curl http://localhost:29987/api/health`
  - Now view the metrics that come back `curl http://localhost:29987/api/metrics`

Metrics should resemble

```text
# HELP web_request_duration_seconds .
# TYPE web_request_duration_seconds histogram
web_request_duration_seconds_sum{path="GET//health"} 261.0
web_request_duration_seconds_count{path="GET//health"} 2
web_request_duration_seconds_bucket{le="0.0",path="GET//health"} 0
web_request_duration_seconds_bucket{le="10.0",path="GET//health"} 0
web_request_duration_seconds_bucket{le="100.0",path="GET//health"} 0
web_request_duration_seconds_bucket{le="1000.0",path="GET//health"} 2
web_request_duration_seconds_bucket{le="10000.0",path="GET//health"} 2
web_request_duration_seconds_bucket{le="50000.0",path="GET//health"} 2
web_request_duration_seconds_bucket{le="100000.0",path="GET//health"} 2
web_request_duration_seconds_bucket{le="500000.0",path="GET//health"} 2
web_request_duration_seconds_bucket{le="1000000.0",path="GET//health"} 2
web_request_duration_seconds_bucket{le="+Inf",path="GET//health"} 2
# EOF
# HELP db_operation_duration_seconds .
# TYPE db_operation_duration_seconds histogram
# EOF

░▒▓    ~/d/r/fuel-indexer    rashad/759-p…middleware-1 *1 +16 !1  curl http://localhost:29987/api/metrics
# HELP web_request_duration_seconds .
# TYPE web_request_duration_seconds histogram
# EOF
# HELP db_operation_duration_seconds .
# TYPE db_operation_duration_seconds histogram
# EOF

{"database_status":"OK","fuel_core_status":"OK","uptime(seconds)":"4"}%

░▒▓    ~/d/r/fuel-indexer    rashad/759-p…middleware-1 *1 +16 !2  cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations

^C  Building [=======================> ] 760/764: fuel-indexer-schema
```

candidates.title: enhancement: add filtering, sorting, and pagination to GraphQL queries
candidates.body:
_This is deekerno speaking as ra0x3. 😉_ 

Closes #637, #656.

## Changelog

- Add `arguments` module for turning query arguments into the new `QueryParams` struct
- Add functionality and tests for the following filter types:
-- `id`: select a record by its ID
-- `and` / `or`: combine two filters together
-- `not`: negate the behavior of a filter
-- `has`: select records that have non-null values for columns in list
-- `in`: select records that have a value matching an element in set
-- `gt` / `gte` / `lt` / `lte` (greater than, etc.): select records whose value satisfies the comparison condition
-- `between`: select records whose value falls between the bounds of the comparison condition
- Add sorting and pagination functionality and tests
- Move stuff specific to GraphQL API queries to fuel-indexer-schema/db/queries.rs
- Add additional variants to GraphQLError
- Update documentation for GraphQL queries and new functionality
- Added support for field aliasing in GraphQL queries
- Add `fuel-indexer-graphql` and `fuel-indexer-graphql-parser` packages

## Testing Plan
I've added extensive testing (15 new tests in total) for filtering and pagination, and unit tests have been adjusted where necessary. CI should pass.

### Manual Testing
Feel free to peruse changes from the documentation PR for example queries that you can use for the block explorer indexer; there are pages for [filtering](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/blob/7e2e798feebd70babf3b5d1caa12b7b59f120c9d/docs/src/reference-guide/components/graphql/queries/search-filtering.md) and [pagination](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/blob/7e2e798feebd70babf3b5d1caa12b7b59f120c9d/docs/src/reference-guide/components/graphql/queries/pagination.md) as well as [this page](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/blob/7e2e798feebd70babf3b5d1caa12b7b59f120c9d/docs/src/reference-guide/components/graphql/queries/full-example.md) that contains a fully-featured example of all of the GraphQL querying functionality being used together (nested entities, sorting, pagination, and filtering).

candidates.title: chore: bump fuels to `v0.40.0`
candidates.body:
Closes #757 
## Context 

`fuels-rs` release a new update. As always we should stay in sync with their latest version, see the release notes [here](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/releases/tag/v0.40.0). This update will enable us to be able to index sway enum values and will unblock #754 and #748. 

## Changelog
• Updates SDK methods, notably using the new `Contract::load_from` and `contract_id()` methods. 
• Use the new cleaner import pattern, see [this](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/releases/tag/v0.40.0) PR for more context. 
• Updates `Cargo.toml` files. 
• Use the newly required generic type `<FuelIndexerTest<WalletUnlocked>`. This will change soon [see this issue](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/925).
• Add new value for `contract_id` field in `fuel_indexer_test.yaml` (the sdk was outputting a new id after the update).

Thanks to @segfault-magnet who unblocked this. 

## Testing 
CI should pass ✅

candidates.title: fix: decode auth signature before recovery
candidates.body:
### Description
- PR fixes an authentication bug by decoding the message signatures before trying to derive a signature

### Testing steps
- [ ] Start a node `cargo run --bin fuel-node`
- [ ] Start the service with auth enabled `cargo  run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --auth-enabled --auth-strategy jwt --jwt-secret 12345677890`
- [ ] Try to authenticate `forc index auth`
- Everything should work the first time (and every subsequent time)

### Changelog
- fix: decode auth signature before recovery

candidates.title: chore: fix dependency location for message ID calculation
candidates.body:
## Changelog
- Fix `sha2` dependency location for codegen

## Testing Plan
CI should pass.

candidates.title: enhancement: compute message ID by using `MessageOut` receipt fields
candidates.body:
Closes #722.

## Changelog
- Compute `message_id` from `MessageOut` receipt fields
- Fix a bug in which the message data from the receipt was being indexed but not the receipt itself
- Fix errant re-name of one of our E2E tests

## Testing Plan
CI should pass. Since the message ID is different on every pass, I couldn't add an assertion to the E2E test. But if you want to be sure that the calculated message ID is exactly the same as the one in the receipt, feel free to replace the first two lines of the `Receipt::MessageOut` match arm with the following:
```
Receipt::MessageOut { sender, recipient, amount, nonce, len, digest, data, message_id } => {
    let computed_message_id = decoder.compute_message_id(&sender, &recipient, nonce, amount, &data[..]);
    Logger::warn!(&format!("These two message IDs should match:\nmessage id from receipt: {}\ncalculated message id: {}\n", message_id, calculated_message_id));
```

Then run `cargo run --bin fuel-node` along and `cargo run --bin web-api` to start up the testing components. After that, run `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --manifest packages/fuel-indexer-tests/components/indices/fuel-indexer-test/fuel_indexer_test.yaml --verbose` to make sure logs are printed. Finally, run `curl -X POST http://127.0.0.1:8000/messageout` and inspect the logs to ensure that the IDs are the same.

candidates.title: breaking: swap uint8 and id types to postgres numeric

labels.name: breaking
labels.description: This is a change that will break some component of the project once merged to origin/develop

candidates.body:
### Description
- Changes to some integer types to `numeric`
  - This gives us more flexibility by allowing us to manually define our own scale and precision for these values
  - Sqlx (and possibly others) use `BigDecimal` to interface with `numeric` PostgresQL types 
    - This `BigDecimal` can be converted into various other simple(r) types 
 - Cleans up the `manifest.rs` module
 - Cleans up and updates tests
 - Fixes native execution
   - We keep forgetting to update native execution when we change things :( 
- The previously broken/skipped tests hidden behind the feature flag now work 🥳 so that flag was removed

### Testing steps
⚠️ This is a non-trivial breaking change, so all testing steps should be checked

- [ ] CI should pass
- [ ] Hello world example should work
- [ ] Block explorer example should work
- [ ] Hello world native example should work


### Changelog
- breaking: swap uint8 and id types to postgres numeric

candidates.title: enhancement: add filtering to GraphQL API queries
candidates.body:
Closes #637.

## Changelog
- Add `arguments` module to `fuel-indexer-schema::db`; this is where all functionality for GraphQL query arguments should be located
- Add `pub fn parse_arguments(..)`; this is the entry point for parsing any query args
-- `todo!()` stubs have been added for sorting and pagination
- Add functionality and tests for the following filter types:
-- `id`: select a record by its ID
-- `and` / `or`: combine two filters together
-- `not`: negate the behavior of a filter
-- `has`: select records that have non-null values for columns in list
-- `in`: select records that have a value matching an element in set
-- `gt` / `gte` / `lt` / `lte` (greater than, etc.): select records whose value satisfies the comparison condition
-- `between`: select records whose value falls between the bounds of the comparison condition
- Move GraphQL API query to DB query functionality from `fuel-indexer-schema/db/lib.rs` to `fuel-indexer-schema/db/queries.rs`
- Add additional variants to `GraphQLError`

## Testing Plan
Added several new tests that check each element in a set of results after filtering as well as ensuring that there are no extra elements that do not satisfy the filter conditions. CI should pass.

### Manual Testing

0. Clear your database and ensure that WASM modules are up-to-date.
1. Start the explorer indexer example with the beta-3 testnet:
```
cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --manifest examples/block-explorer/explorer-indexer/explorer_indexer.manifest.yaml
```
1. Open the playground for the example: `http://localhost:29987/api/playground/fuel_examples/explorer_indexer`.
2. Run the following query; notice that there are many results (this is the non-filtered example):
```
query {
  tx {
    id
    timestamp
    value
    hash
    status
    block {
    	id
    	height
    	timestamp
        hash
    }
  }
}
```
3. Run the following query; ensure that there are three results returned (this example shows multiple filters on one entity [comprised of a complex comparison and simple comparison, which are joined together by a logical operator]).
```
query {
  tx {
    id
    timestamp
    value
    hash
    status
    block(filter: { height: { between: { min: 10, max: 15 } }, and: { timestamp: { lt: 1678484680 } } } ) {
    	id
    	height
    	timestamp
        hash
    }
  }
}
```
4. Run the following query; ensure that there are now only two results returned (this example shows that multiple entities can be filtered in the same query [this is also an example for the membership filter]):
```
query {
  tx(filter: { hash: { in: ["adbf1b802450b4782358ff05661ef784a1c6ed47ad7b0cca645ff8fb75debb26", "9c6db9e9d75c2b357931ff7055af2da612a4017ccfe1af71b70ca88c22c9e2e3"] } } ) {
    id
    timestamp
    value
    hash
    status
    block(filter: { height: { between: { min: 10, max: 15 } }, and: { timestamp: { lt: 1678484680 } } } ) {
    	id
    	height
    	timestamp
        hash
    }
  }
}
```

## Notes
Documentation updates will come in a separate PR so that this one doesn't get even bigger.

_This implementation uses a fork of [`graphql-parser`](https://github.com/graphql-rust/graphql-parser)._ The original version of the crate does not allow for parsing numbers greater than `i64::MAX` (as its internal number type is hard-coded to an `i64`); we allow for storing `u64` and `u128`, so we need to figure out a way to parse `u64`s and `u128`s from valid GraphQL queries. As such, I've forked `graphql-parser` and added the necessary functionality; you can find the fork [here](https://github.com/FuelLabs/graphql-parser) and the diff for the changes [here](https://github.com/FuelLabs/graphql-parser/commit/c37eddb9a12a7f7e5a2c7b07f8cd16645e909e9f); it should be noted that the original crate has not released a new version in quite some time so there should be minimal burden from upstream changes.

candidates.title: enhancement: support many contracts one manifest
candidates.body:
Closes #697

@Braqzen requested this feature, where many contractIds can be passed into a single manifest for use by a single indexer. This PR adds that functionality.

## Changelog
• Updates the`Manifest.contract_id` field to be of enum type `ContractIds`
• Updates the `indexer.rs` to handle which variant of the enum is passed. 
• Implements `FromStr for ContractIds`
• Adds the functions `fn contract_id_from_str` and `contract_id_to_str`. See note Below

## Notes
1. In order to maintain ergonomic input from our manifest files, I had to implement custom serialization and deserialization on the `contract_id` field using the `serde_json` crate. This is so that a user can do any of these in their manifest, and it will all be valid. 

```
contract_id : ~
contract_id: fuel1234
contract_id: 
   - fuel1234
   - fuel5678
contract_id: [fuel1234, fuel5678]
```
The multi-line array format is the standard for yaml, but a single-line array is also valid, both will work here. 

2. Currently if the contracts have different ABIs and therefor different types, a single indexer will not able to index both of these different contract ABIs. This functionality is outside the scope of this PR.

## Testing 
Initially I had bolted on a lot of additional logic in order to write an integration test for this, but it seemed to add a lot bloat for one case, so that was removed.

For manual testing, change one of the test `manifest.yaml` files. For each of the following yaml field formats, build the wasm binary. If you want you can also run the ci-test-suite locally for each change; I have done this on my side.   
```
contract_id: [fuel123]
contract_id: 
   - fuel123
contract_id: fuel123
```

candidates.title: chore: upgrade `wasmer` to v2.3.0
candidates.body:
## Changelog
- Upgrade `wasmer` from `v2.0` to `v2.3`

## Testing Plan
Tests should pass. Each example should pass as well.

## Notes
_No changes in functionality_; this is just an upgrade to bring in some fixes for memory leaks and the like that have been added after `wasmer`'s `v2.0` release. We should still investigate refactoring to use `v3.0` or above, just at a later time.

candidates.title: chore: bump fuels from `v0.37` to `v0.38.1`
candidates.body:
closes #693 

## Changelog
• Updates Cargo.toml's to use the the latest `fuels` version. 
• Updates `RUSTC_VERSION` env var in CI.
• Updates root Cargo.toml to rust `v.1.68.1`
• Removes `check-rustc` version. This was throwing a false negative. It might be an order of operations problem, where the toolchain needs to download the `RUSTC_VERSION` first, then we run this job. I'll add this back in in another PR. 
` Updates `fuels` method calls to use the latest api. Notably `Contract::load_contract` `TxParameters::new` and `CallParameters::new` have been updated. 

## Testing
All tests should pass.

candidates.title: chore: cleanup plugin command opts

labels.name: breaking
labels.description: This is a change that will break some component of the project once merged to origin/develop

candidates.body:
### Description
- Changes the `--output-dir-root` flag in `forc index build` and `forc index deploy` to a `--target-dir` flag in order to be more aligned [with the `cargo` `--target-dir` flag](https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/config.html#configuration-keys)
- Also does some cleanup
- Renames some things to "indexer" for consistency slash so that they will work
- Fixes the `--run-migrations` flag in fuel-indexer so you don't have to `--run-migrations <VALUE>`, you just `--run-migrations`
- Updates docs

### Testing steps
- [ ] CI should pass
- [ ] Ensure flag still works
  - `cargo build -p forc-index --release`
  - `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --fuel-node-host node-beta-2.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80`
  - `./target/release/forc-index deploy --path examples/block-explorer/explorer-indexer --target-dir /path/to/repos/fuel-indexer --release`

### Changelog
breaking: Swap `--output-dir-root` flag in `forc index {build,deploy}` to `--target-dir`

chosen_pr.title: fix: update docs/examples
chosen_pr.body:
### Description
- PR does a few things
  - Updates docs for the examples
  - Removes `api-server` and `fuel-core-lib` feature flagging from native execution
  - Fixes a bug in `forc index deploy` where the `--path` isn't respected relative to the `--target-dir`

### Testing steps 
- [ ] Build plugin locally `cargo build -p forc-index --release --locked`
- [ ] Start fuel node `cargo run -p fuel-node --bin fuel-node`
- [ ] Start the service `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations`
- [ ] `cd examples/block-explorer && forc-index deploy --path explorer-indexer --target-dir /path/to/fuel-indexer` 
  - This ☝🏽 would fail on master


### Changelog 
- docs: update docs for examples 
- fix: ensure that `forc index deploy` respects `--path` relative to `--target-dir`

chosen_detail.title: fix: update docs/examples
chosen_detail.body:
### Description
- PR does a few things
  - Updates docs for the examples
  - Removes `api-server` and `fuel-core-lib` feature flagging from native execution
  - Fixes a bug in `forc index deploy` where the `--path` isn't respected relative to the `--target-dir`

### Testing steps 
- [ ] Build plugin locally `cargo build -p forc-index --release --locked`
- [ ] Start fuel node `cargo run -p fuel-node --bin fuel-node`
- [ ] Start the service `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations`
- [ ] `cd examples/block-explorer && forc-index deploy --path explorer-indexer --target-dir /path/to/fuel-indexer` 
  - This ☝🏽 would fail on master


### Changelog 
- docs: update docs for examples 
- fix: ensure that `forc index deploy` respects `--path` relative to `--target-dir`

repo.name: fuel-indexer
repo.description: *Archived* 🗃 The Fuel indexer is a standalone service that can be used to index various components of the Fuel blockchain.
